config.title: Sleep self-assessment
config.intro_title: Do you have a sleep problem?
config.intro_copy:
Most people experience problems with sleep in their life. it is thought that a third of people in the UK have an episode of insomnia at some point.

This short test from Sleepio is designed to find out if you are experiencing symptoms of insomnia. It will also give you practical tips and advice for improving your sleep.
config.intro_copy_alt:
Most people experience problems with sleep in their life. In fact, it's thought that a third of Brits will have episodes of insomnia at some point. 

The causes can include physical conditions, psychological conditions (such as depression or anxiety) or a combination of both.

This short test from Sleepio will give you a 'sleep score' plus practical tips and advice for improving your sleep.
config.intro_foot: Based on the Sleepio sleep test. Reproduced with permission. Copyright© 2012 Big Health Ltd.

q.title: New question
q.body: Thinking about a typical night in the last month, how long does it take you to fall asleep?

q.title: New question
q.body: Thinking about a typical night in the last month, if you wake up, how long are you awake for in total?

q.title: New question
q.body: Thinking about the last month, how many nights a week do you have a problem with your sleep?

q.title: New question
q.body: Thinking about a typical night in the last month, how would you rate your sleep quality?

q.title: New question
q.body: Thinking about the past month, to what extent has poor sleep affected your mood, energy, or relationships?

q.title: New question
q.body: Thinking about the past month, to what extent has poor sleep affected your concentration, productivity, or ability to stay awake?

q.title: New question
q.body: Thinking about the past month, to what extent has poor sleep troubled you in general?

q.title: New question
q.body: How long have you had a problem with your sleep?

a.body: I don't have a problem (or I've had a problem for less than one month)

results.ri:
Your sleep score is very poor and the answers you have given indicate that you're experiencing a number of symptoms of insomnia. Episodes of insomnia are common, in fact, it's estimated that a third of us will struggle with it at some time in our lives. 

There are various things you can do to help you get to sleep. This is often referred to as 'good sleep hygiene'. For example:
  • avoid caffeine later in the day
  • avoid alcohol as this is known to disturb sleep
  • avoid heavy meals late at night
  • stick to regular times to go to bed and get up
  • use thick curtains, blinds or an eye mask to stop you being woken up by light
  • try earplugs to stop any noise disturbing you
  • try taking a warm bath an hour before you go to bed
  • try listening to calming music or reading a book
  • avoid watching TV or using mobile devices in the bedroom
However, if your sleep problems are affecting your daily life, it’s time to see your GP. You could take the results of this test to discuss with your GP or, even better, keep a sleep diary for two weeks before you go. Check useful links for a range of information and advice.

Your sleep score is OK but some of the answers you have given indicate that you're experiencing a few symptoms of insomnia. Episodes of insomnia are common, in fact, it's estimated that a third of us will struggle with it at some time in our lives. 

There are various things you can do to help you get to sleep. This is often referred to as 'good sleep hygiene'. For example:
  • avoid caffeine later in the day
  • avoid alcohol as this is known to disturb sleep
  • avoid heavy meals late at night
  • stick to regular times to go to bed and get up
  • use thick curtains, blinds or an eye mask to stop you being woken up by light
  • try earplugs to stop any noise disturbing you
  • try taking a warm bath an hour before you go to bed
  • try listening to calming music or reading a book
  • avoid watching TV or using mobile devices in the bedroom
If your sleep problems are affecting your daily life, it’s time to see your GP. You could take the results of this test to discuss with your GP or, even better, keep a sleep diary for two weeks before you go. Check useful links for a range of information and advice.

Your sleep score is good and doesn't indicate that you're struggling with insomnia at the moment. Episodes of insomnia are common though and it's estimated that a third of us will struggle with it at some time in our lives. Stress and anxiety are common triggers.

There are various good habits we should all get into to maximise our chances of a good night's sleep. This is often referred to as 'good sleep hygiene'. For example:
  • avoid caffeine later in the day
  • avoid alcohol as this is known to disturb sleep
  • avoid heavy meals late at night
  • stick to regular times to go to bed and get up
  • use thick curtains, blinds or an eye mask to stop you being woken up by light
  • try earplugs to stop any noise disturbing you
  • try taking a warm bath an hour before you go to bed
  • try listening to calming music or reading a book
  • avoid watching TV or using mobile devices in the bedroom
Check useful links for a range of further information and advice.

Your sleep score is excellent and indicates that you're not struggling with insomnia at the moment. Episodes of insomnia are common though and it's estimated that a third of us will struggle with it at some time in our lives. Stress and anxiety are common triggers.

There are various good habits we should all get into to maximise our chances of a good night's sleep. This is often referred to as 'good sleep hygiene'. For example:
  • avoid caffeine later in the day
  • avoid alcohol as this is known to disturb sleep
  • avoid heavy meals late at night
  • stick to regular times to go to bed and get up
  • use thick curtains, blinds or an eye mask to stop you being woken up by light
  • try earplugs to stop any noise disturbing you
  • try taking a warm bath an hour before you go to bed
  • try listening to calming music or reading a book
  • avoid watching TV or using mobile devices in the bedroom
Check useful links for a range of further information and advice.
